review_blob: Four-pack after waiting in line to pick up Lawsons Sip of Sunshine. Was actually offered Heady as well so figured I better take it. Brewer recommends drinking it straight from can, however, its color is one of the strongest traits. Orange-cloudy is pretty darn close to perfect. Citrus aroma a plus as well. Piney-citrus taste-too bitter for my taste.Clean finish. A good beer but I have trouble understanding the hype. Can name a number of Vermont beers Id rather drink before this.

Howler Purchased at brewerys tap room in S. Burlington,VT. Enjoy the hazy, yellow-gold color and its aroma with banana and pear as well as a bready smell. Fruity, bready, grassy tastes with light carbonation. A watery aftertaste is a negative, however, a very nice beer. Glad to see them in my neighborhood!

Bomber poured into tulip. Foamy brown head. Black licorice and coffee aroma with peanutty undertones. Licorice-medicine taste with a little peanut. Lingering bitter aftertaste. Would have loved more of that peanut taste that would have cancelled out more of the bitter, porter taste. I admit that Im not the biggest fan of porters, but try BBCs Barta before this if you are a fan of the style and the brewery.

Poured out of 12oz can into tulip glass. Great golden-red color and sweet, citrus aroma. Mango taste mixed with grass and evergreen. Piney aftertaste with medium carbonation. Tried it in the winter but may be a great summer beer although it may be on the bitter side.

Poured out of bomber. Dark brown color (more reddish brown if held up to bright light) with a light brown frothy head that quickly dissipates. Bread and licorice aroma. The taste seems to come out more in the aftertaste, where one can more easily distinguish fruit and smoky tastes. Medium carbonation. Its a good-tasting beer but not as good as other brews from these guys. Probably wont pay for this stuff again

Growler from Brewery. Pours a light brown head that quickly dissapates. Coffee and medicine-like aromas. Tastes of coffee, licorice, and fruit (prunes?) Medium carbonation with a distinct coffee aftertaste. Glad I bought the growler but not sure why the coffee porter thing is so big these days.

Purchased bomber at Winooski Beverage. Poured a medium with golden-orange color (maybe the best looking beer Ive seen in a while) Citrus, bread, spruce aromas. Medium carbonation with piney, citrus aftertaste. Difficult for me to describe the taste. Yet I liked it in the beginning of a glass, not so crazy about it in the middle, but I drank it down quickly in the end. Maybe due to the 7% alcohol...

Bomber. Been wanting to try this one as its brewed over hot rocks and my wife works with brewers wife. Very nice copper-light brown color with thin, white head and smoky, sweet aroma. Taste caramel, toast, coffee, and smoke but not one dominant. Light carbonation. Give this one a try when you can.

Pint can poured into tulip. Foamy head on top of golden, yellow color. Aroma of juniper and lemon. Taste the ginger and juniper from the gin - along with sour lemon from it?s saison qualities. Very crisp, dry finish with low-to-medium carbonation. Try it if you want to experience "gin-aging" beer.

16 oz. can from 4-pack purchased at Craft Beer Cellar in Waterbury, VT. Pours with little-to-almost no head and a medium-golden color. Citrus, evergreen, and bready aroma. Light carbonation and clean finish with noticeable citrus (grapefruit peel) taste. Highly drinkable and tasty.
beer_name: Lost Nation Mosaic Single Hop IPA

review_blob: Light golden color with frothy head that quickly dissapates. Aroma of evergreen and grapefruit. Very strong grapefruit taste with medium carbonation and clean finish. It started more difficult to drink than I expected at first but eased up after a few sips and showed its session-able characteristics. Nice.
beer_name: Evil Twin / 7venth Sun Citra Sunshine Slacker

review_blob: 22oz bottle that pours hazy yellowish with a medium head. Relatively light carbonation that leave a lingering aftertaste sort of like grapefruit juice. Sour, funky aroma and grapefruit taste - maybe even like peel.
beer_name: Evil Twin / Intangible Ales Sour Bikini

review_blob: Pours a medium frothy head out of bottle. Strong citrus/grapefruit aroma and taste with some pine/spruce and grapefruit peel finish. Like another rater mentioned, there is a watery taste as well. Light carbonation and clean finish. A nice beer that I hope to see around many places.

Very nice dark gold/light brown color with thin head when poured. Coffee-dominant aroma, of course. Youll also get a bitter taste with the coffee yet the smoothness of a cream ale fights through a little. Higher than average carbonation with the coffee aftertaste. Not sure if Ill buy another six-pack of this but would order in bar or restaurant.
beer_name: Ballast Point Calm Before The Storm

review_blob: Purchased growler at brewery after sons ski meet in next-door Craftsbury. Pours a frothy, thin head with golden-yellow color. Citrus and bread aromas but piney-citrus taste dominates. Medium-light carbonation with grapefruit peel aftertaste. One of best beers Ive had since summer.

Purchased growler at brewery on way home from Craftsbury Outdoor Center. Was recommended by employee and she was right! Pours a frothy, thick head with piney and citrus aroma. Both dominate the taste as well. Evergreen and Grapefruit are certainly in the aftertaste. Lighter carbonation than other beers I?ve tasted. I wouldn?t call it Hill Farmstead?s best beer but it really is excellent - as their beers are.

Bomber. A nice looking beer with a golden brown color. Aroma and taste of bread and citrus - both very slight. Medium carbonation with a clean finish. I like the beer though not as good as Gose the Destroyer. Would drink it again but wont be a go-to.
Howler purchased at Brewery. Cloudy orange-yellow color with medium head. Pine and citrus aroma. Piney, wheaty taste with grapefruit. Fizzy on the tongue. A nice beer from a nice place.

Bottle purchased @ Growler Garage (S. Burlington, VT). Poured medium white head and very nice golden color. Aroma of lime and grass - possibly, even some graham cracker crust. Certainly a sour brew. Strong lime taste with grass and other citrus. Leaves a citrus rind aftertaste that coats tongue and mouth. I enjoy lime...I enjoy key lime pie...Im not a big fan of sour beers, though. Its an enjoyable beer...something different, for sure. Have no problem stopping after one.
beer_name: Crooked Stave / Hawkshead Key Lime Tau (2)

review_blob: Purchased bomber at Beverage Warehouse in Winooski, VT. Pours a cloudy, light yellow color with a head that quickly dissipates. Not as salty as other Goses I have tried which makes it a refreshing beer. Citrus aromas and taste. Does have a lighter palate than its looks may assume. A surprisingly good summer beer that would be good all year round.

This may be one of the nicest looking beers I can remember pouring with a golden, light brown color and a frothy head. Definitely pick up a piney, spruce aroma - possibly, a little citrus. The taste is harder to describe beside the bitterness - which isnt too overpowering. The piney/sprucey thing comes up with the taste as well. With 103 IBUs, this beer leaves an aftertaste. Not a beer to have when youre having more than one but a neat beer for sure. Heard about it for a while and glad I finally had one.

Purchased howler at Growler Garage - sampled first with flight. Caramel color with spruce aroma. Taste citrus, piney and, maybe, banana?? Nice carbonation with a really clean finish. Overall, a kinder, gentler pale ale. Smoother than one may expect. Thats what surprised me. From what Ive experienced so far, I wonder if Zero Gravity can make any mistakes.

Six pack of sixteen-ounce cans. Figured I try a new Shandy as June soon approaching and I like Gansett as far as cheap beers go.

Poured with large, frothy head and yellowish color. Definitely a fruity aroma (lets say...lemon). What I like about this is the overpowering lemon taste over the beer. What I dont like is the lack of carbonation. Too bad they couldnt have found that balance. 

Also, bit of a steep price for a cheap beer. Can probably buy higher quality shandys for the same or less. As one review stated, would be nicer to have a good lemonade and a good beer. Yet, I wont mind drinking down the other five cans...its not that, that bad.

Poured with medium head that quickly dissipated. Could easily smell citrus and hoppy aroma. Light yellow color. Definitely notice citrus and hops in taste but not too overpowering - would have liked to tasted a little more citrus this time of year. Light to medium carbonation with very light, crisp finish. Nice beer but wont make my short list when I go out to buy beer or when at a bar/restaurant.

Filled up at Growler Garage in S. Burlington, VT. Listed there as Saison - not IPA. Poured light to medium head with clear, golden color. Bready, grassy, fruity aroma. Totally taste the citrus along with spicy undertones. Relatively clean on the tongue. Nice...not Wow, but nice...may have a hard time choosing between this and the good ol Standard, Magic Hat #9, on a nice afternoon at the end of a work week if a local establishment were offering both.
beer_name: Burlington Beer Surfing Waves of Dopamine

review_blob: Purchased two drafts at Bluebird Barbecue in Burlington, VT. Hazy, yellow-orange-gloden appearance with medium to minimal head. Clearly taste citrus (more on the grapefruit) and pine. Relatively clean on the palate but more intense carbonation than I remember with other Hill Farmstead varieties. May be my favorite of the bunch from Greensboro that Ive tried.
beer_name: Hill Farmstead Mosaic Single Hop Pale Ale

review_blob: Purchased bottle at brewery. Pours with frothy head that quickly dissipates. Golden-yellowish color. Lemony, grassy aroma. Certainly has a sour tastw one would expect with a saison but with a honey-sweet finish. Lightly carbonated and crisp on the tongue. Enjoyable.
Purchased growler at local beverage mart. Pours medium-sized frothy head. Very nice caramel color. Toasty, spruce flavors with medium carbonation leaving a bitter aftertaste.

Growler purchase. Pours with minimal, light brown head and medium brown color. Roasty, coffee aromas, yet, a much lighter taste and palate than one may expect for a brown ale since it is a SESSION ale. More bitter than one may expect out of a session. As one who grew up next to 14th Stars hometown, would have like to noticed more of a maple taste. Name seems more of a gimmick.
Growler fill that pours with minimal head and has citrus aroma. Spruce and grapefruit taste with low carbonation and quick finish. Incredibly smooth and easy - drinking beer.

Purchased bottle at brewery. Pours with ample head and a light hazy yellow color. Aroma of hay and citrus. Citrusy (sp) taste as well along with some floral undertones. A clean palate with light carbonation. Im not the most experienced with saisons but have drank more in the past year and this is the best I have had.
beer_name: Hill Farmstead / Kissmeyer / Cambridge Nordic Saison

review_blob: Purchased growler from brewery. Pours a frothy head. Aroma is sweeter than I was expecting. Was thinking about something more of a Newcastle when I think Brown Ale as far as taste but this is way stronger and much more complex. Noticing strong coffee taste with lesser touches of toffee and caramel. Leaves bitter, lingering aftertaste.

Purchased growler refill at brewery. Poured with foamy head that quickly dissipated. Aroma of citrus and pine/spruce. Certainly taste the citrus - more on the grapefruit. Has a medium body with average carbonation and a bitter finish. Only wish I was drinking this in the spring or summer rather than early January.
beer_name: Hill Farmstead Citra Single Hop Pale Ale

review_blob: Purchased growler refills at brewery. Poured with frothy head that dissipated quickly. Aroma of grapefruit and hay. Medium carbonation with crisp aftertaste. Brewing with honey may just make this less bitter than normal IPAs, which impressed me at brewery tasting. Dont worry - theres still the citrus, spruce taste one may expect in an IPA. this is just different. Better, I think.

Purchased growler at brewery. First bought some last spring and loved it. This should be your go-to beer when you go out to dinner, if available, Winter 2014-15.Poured with minimal head and easy to notice coffee-toffee-caramel aroma. For something as dark as this, one may expect something stronger, however, here is the real surprise. It?s a much lighter flavor with light carbonation and a much cleaner finish than one may expect on the tongue. Taste some licorice along with a bready, earthy flavor. Long story short...think about Newcastle crossed a scotch ale. If you?re in the Burlington area, please give Infinity - and 80 Shilling - a chance.

Purchased howler at brewery. Poured dark brown with light to medium light brown head. Coffee, herb aroma with woody, smoky taste. Light carbonation with a medium finish. A nice dark beer to enjoy in the fall and winter months.

You know, I think that I found the secret to Unibroues process...make a quality beer and then make it taste a little worse by throwing some spices (or more spices) in the recipe. 

Poured out of a bomber purchased at local beverage store. Has a medium head that sticks round along with a bready, coffee aroma and reddish - brown color (cherry cola was my favorite deScription when reading other reviews). Actually, color may be its strongest attribute. Maudie seemed to be more bubbly than other Unibroues that Ive sampled, save, Ephemere. It has a full body and the spices give it a long finish. The first taste I had of Maudite was amazing with a balance of bitter and sweet. I thought that this beer was as good as the reviews that I had read some time ago. 

And then the spices kicked in....Im not going to even to try to describe what they are. What Ill write is that my first glass started out great, was tougher in the middle, and then finished well (maybe it was due to the 8% alcohol content). I had my second glass two nights later after storing the rest in a small Sodastream bottle. That one seemed to drink better all the way through as I was expecting the spice. I know those folks up in Quebec (who have shown that there is more to Canadian beer than Molson and Labatts) like to brew in the Belgian style, which may include a lot of spices. I know Stella Artois doesnt use them - at least, to excess. May need to do some research...
UPDATED: DEC 14, 2014

Pleasing golden appearance with medium head. Grassy, herby, citrus aroma. Light carbonation, quick finish with better - than - average lager taste. Usually dont buy lager from microbreweries but enjoyed this howler.

Has a citrusy, herby aroma but the clear light brown appearance may be Bengalis greatest asset. Its pretty darn nice. Thin, oily texture with a surprisingly abrupt finish. Im not a big IPA fan but was surprised and pleased by the medium bitter taste of this brew - the second from Sixpoint after Sweet Action - which I totally forgot to review (and would give a higher rating).

My wife loves this beer and she drinks very little beer to start with in the first place.

The only down side of this brew is the price as its twice the price as the lowest price selection at the Growler Garage in S. Burlington, VT. Maybe my nose is stuffy but Im not catching much of an aroma. Maybe its because Im drinking out of a pint glass with it half-empty/half-full..

Anyway, it is a cloudy, reddish beer with a lively carbonation and a surprisingly abrupt finish. One can surely taste the strawberries, which cuts the bitterness but not too much. Its not as light as on May expect for a fruit beer, which is why I was impressed with it at first sip (though I didnt refill my growler that time due to the price).
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2014

I had my first pint at the legendary,Fire and Ice restaurant down the street from the Otter Creek brewery - and the draft experience was superior. For this review, Im drinking out of a can. The beer poured out had an initial foamy that settled to a thin head. The aroma was dominated by, well, citrus! The citrus taste reminds me do grapefruit, especially in the aftertaste. With that being said, it has a bitter finish that follows a thin texture and lively carbonation. Overall, Im not a big fan of IPAs but Ive been drinking multiple cans of this during the summer.

Pouring La Fin du Monde is pleasant, especially if you have a bomber with cork version. Its quick to notice the bready, citrusy, spicy aroma. The brews golden, orange, color is its greatest attribute. If its minimal head didnt dissipate so quickly, Id have rated the appearance 5/5. It has a medium body, lively carbonation and a finish that lingers. 

Then theres the taste...maybe its the wrong time of year to be drinking a brew where spices seem to dominate the taste so much - especially in a lighter beer. Tastes like a seasonal beer Id have have around Christmas or other months in the winter. 

Maybe Ill give it a try when the leaves are turning or have fallen off the trees.

Has a slight citrus aroma with orange, hazy color and a minimal head. The citrusy, hoppy taste is lightly sour with medium body and a quick, bitter, finish.

Overall...if its Hill Farmstead, its got to be good!

A citrus and piney/spruced aroma with a minimal head. Lightly bitter taste with citrus as well. Has a crisp and very clean finish. Much lighter than Hills flagship Edward brew. Worth the drive and wait. Thank a deity if you come across it on tap.

Purchased a howler at the local bevy-mart after noticing it hailed from my hometown. I checked out their website (which is a Facebook page - time to upgrade, boys!). They mentioned their Windsor Ale and they noted that it wasnt like your normal darker ale and they were right.

It had a thin to minimal head with a nutty, floral aroma. The cloudy, brown ale tasted bitter but much, much smoother and lighter than one may expect - just what the brewers wrote. I would say that it has a medium body and slick texture with a long finish. Would say it has coffee and citrus tastes if having those together in a darker ale is possible.

Bottom line is Im glad that I tried it and will look for as the leaves turn here in Vermont - which will be sooner rather than later. This is a brew that could compete with other popular local favorites over the next long Vermont fall/winter/spring if folks will give it a try

Had a pint- well, twenty ounces - in Old Montreal last week. Was amazed, to say the least, when I avoid Canadian beers at home in Vermont in favor for local craft brews. But, When in Rome...."

Wow! This is light years ahead of the Molsons and Labatts that I drank in the 80s and early 90s before the microbrewery movement in the US put us ahead of our pals to the north, in my opinion. But enough history...to the Beer!

A large cloudy glass of golden beer with a small, frothy head was brought to the table as I was waiting for my Poutine topped with Smoked Meat (again when in Rome). There was a fruity aroma - definitely orange - with a similar taste. Gotta say that it was one of the better beers Ive had in a while and appreciated the long finish. My wife, who is not a beer drinker, was very impressed! 

Best beer Ive ever had? Not that sure. Yet, this certainly convinced me that our Canadian friends realized loud and clear that American (micro)brewers moved American beer ahead of theirs and Unibroue has been fighting back hard for their countrys honor. Ill be looking for this at my favorite beer places along with local and brews that Ive never tried. Hope to go back to Montreal soon and will purchase some to bring back over the border if need be.
